q: What is cellulitis?
a: Cellulitis is a skin infection that causes painful, hot, and swollen skin. It can be serious if not treated quickly.

q: How is cellulitis treated?
a: Cellulitis is treated with antibiotics. For mild cases, antibiotic tablets are prescribed for a week. If severe, hospital treatment may be necessary.

q: What are the symptoms of cellulitis?
a: Symptoms of cellulitis include painful, hot, and swollen skin. Redness and blistering may also occur, along with swollen and painful glands.

q: Can cellulitis spread to other parts of the body?
a: Yes, if not treated quickly, cellulitis can spread to other parts of the body such as the blood, muscles, and bones.

q: What can I do to help speed up the recovery from cellulitis?
a: In addition to taking antibiotics, you can help speed up recovery by taking painkillers, elevating the affected body part, moving the joint near the affected part, and staying hydrated.

q: How can I reduce the chances of getting cellulitis again?
a: To reduce the chances of getting cellulitis again, keep the skin clean and moisturized, clean cuts and wounds, wear appropriate clothing and footwear to prevent cuts and scrapes, and promptly treat athlete's foot.

q: When should I seek urgent advice for cellulitis?
a: Seek urgent advice if your skin is painful, hot, and swollen. Early treatment can prevent cellulitis from becoming more serious.

q: What causes cellulitis?
a: Cellulitis is usually caused by a bacterial infection. It can occur when the skin is broken, such as from an insect bite or cut, or if the skin is cracked and dry.

q: Can cellulitis be life-threatening?
a: Yes, if not treated quickly, cellulitis can lead to serious complications that can be life-threatening.

q: Who is more at risk of developing cellulitis?
a: People with poor circulation, difficulty in mobility, weakened immune systems, lymphedema, a history of cellulitis, or individuals who inject drugs or have wounds from surgery are at a higher risk of developing cellulitis.

q: What should you do if you have severe cellulitis symptoms?
i: If you have cellulitis with a very high temperature, a fast heartbeat or breathing, purple patches on your skin, feeling dizzy or faint, confusion or disorientation, cold and clammy skin, or unresponsiveness, you should immediately call 999 or go to A&E.

a: Some individuals with recurring cellulitis may be prescribed low-dose long-term antibiotics to prevent future infections.
